description: From Middle English lerned, lernd, lernyd, equivalent to learn +‎ -ed, which replaced the earlier lered (“taught”), from Old English (ġe)lǣred, past participle of lǣran (“to teach”). Learn formerly had the meaning “to teach”, which is now found only in nonstandard speech, as well as its standard meaning of “to learn”.

adjectives.description: learned (comparative more learned, superlative most learned)

entries.meaning: Having much learning, knowledgeable, erudite; highly educated.
examples: Synonyms: brainy, erudite, knowledgeable, scholarly, educated; see also Thesaurus:learned

entries.meaning: (law, formal) A courteous description used in various ways to refer to lawyers or judges.

adjectives.description: learned (comparative more learned, superlative most learned)

entries.meaning: Derived from experience; acquired by learning.
examples: Everyday behavior is an overlay of learned behavior over instinct.

entries.meaning: (Canada, US and dialectal English) simple past tense and past participle of learn
